skill.name: form-testing
skill.description: Test WordPress form submissions and email delivery. Validates contact forms, checks WP Mail SMTP configuration, and sends test emails. Use when verifying form functionality or troubleshooting email delivery issues.

security_audit.summary: The form-testing skill has limited security risk. It primarily executes Docker commands and WP-CLI operations for legitimate WordPress email testing purposes. The script reads SMTP configuration and sends test emails through WordPress's built-in wp_mail() function.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded email address in script
low_findings.description: The test-mail.sh script contains a hardcoded email address (admin@csrdevelopment.com) as the default recipient. This could potentially expose internal email addresses if the script is shared or used in different environments.

content.user_title: Test WordPress Forms and Email Delivery
content.value_statement: WordPress contact forms often fail silently, causing lost leads and frustrated users. This skill tests form submissions, validates email delivery, and diagnoses SMTP configuration issues to ensure your forms work reliably.
actual_capabilities: Tests WordPress email delivery via wp_mail() function
Validates WP Mail SMTP plugin configuration
Checks SMTP server connectivity and settings
Sends test emails with detailed diagnostics
Provides color-coded terminal output for easy reading
Displays WordPress and PHP version information
limitations: Requires Docker container access for WordPress sites
Only tests email functionality, not form UI/UX
Default recipient email must be customized
Cannot test external SMTP services directly

use_cases.title: Debug Email Delivery Issues
use_cases.description: Quickly diagnose why contact form emails aren't reaching inboxes by testing SMTP configuration and mail server connectivity.

use_cases.title: Validate Form Functionality
use_cases.description: Automate testing of contact forms after deployments to ensure submissions work and emails are delivered properly.

use_cases.title: Verify SMTP Setup
use_cases.description: Confirm WP Mail SMTP plugin is configured correctly and test email delivery without manual form submissions.

best_practices: Always test email delivery after configuring WP Mail SMTP to verify settings are correct
Use staging environments first before testing on production sites to avoid sending test emails to real users
Document your SMTP configuration settings for team members who need to troubleshoot email issues
anti_patterns: Don't test with real customer email addresses - use test emails or your own address
Avoid testing email delivery on live production sites during business hours
Never share SMTP credentials in documentation or commit them to version control

faq.question: Is this compatible with all WordPress setups?
faq.answer: The skill requires Docker-based WordPress installations and WP-CLI access. It works with any WordPress site running in a Docker container.

faq.question: What are the testing limits?
faq.answer: There's no hard limit on test emails, but SMTP providers may have daily sending limits. The skill sends one test email per execution.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, the script is designed for automation and returns appropriate exit codes for success/failure, making it suitable for continuous integration workflows.

faq.question: Is my data safe during testing?
faq.answer: The skill only reads WordPress configuration and sends test emails. It doesn't store or transmit any sensitive data externally beyond the test email itself.

faq.question: What if the test email fails?
faq.answer: The script will display error messages from PHPMailer and WordPress, helping you identify configuration issues, authentication problems, or server connectivity issues.

faq.question: How does this compare to other email testing tools?
faq.answer: Unlike external email testing services, this skill tests the actual WordPress email system with your specific SMTP configuration, providing more accurate results for WordPress-specific issues.
